comment:
Aroma slightly overpowered by alcohol but has floral and vanilla undertones. 
Taste begins soft with slight alcohol rasp vanilla and caramel undertones kicked with an alcohol rasp and nice warmth in the chest.

Solid pour for the price!

Background: 
I often buy a budget bourbon and leave it at my girlfriend’s house. That way, if I’m feeling a dram, I have something nearby. My girlfriend, also, likes whiskey and will make a hot toddy for a nightcap. 
So I look for versatile, tasty bourbons that won’t break the bank...

Here’s the short version: Hot hot hot!Just expect OGD114 to give you a nice big, spicy ethanol hug.

Once acclimated, I get honeyed sweetness, citrus, vanilla, caramel, and spice on the nose. 

On the taste, it’s hot and spicy! Cinnamon, cloves, hay, and mint. The rye is very apparent in this whiskey. There’s a underlying hint of citrus there too. At the end, I get that bit of nuttiness that’s common in Beam products.

Overall: 
This is a solid budget pick. My bourbon preferences tend to lean towards high rye bourbons. I like that spice! It’s a decent pour and will hold it’s own as a mixer. Will it unseat my current budget bourbon: Wild Turkey 101? No...but it’s a good and wallet friendly! This is a 3.5 for me but gets extra points for the price.
“Kentucky hug”. with BigRed heat.  Numb lips. Tingly tongue. Superb value $20 bottle.
Still amazing for the price, watered down to 40%
For being bottom shelf this stuff is great. This time I opted to water it down and glad I did.

Nose: Dusty leather, cinnamon rolls, rye spice, dark fruits, molasses.

Taste: Wood, cherry, chocolate, peanuts, maple syrup.

Notes:  a true "value" bottle. Lots of proof, good flavor, a fine nose, and looong finish. A rare find for $25
Hot. Not in my wheelhouse. More on the Knob Creek realm of flavor. Not for me
Ethanol and cinnamon on the nose / taste Deep butterscotch, vanilla, cherries, touch mint / finish sweet cinnamon heat.

Got this bottle because of all of the hype it was getting and being a great “deal”. Personally I just don’t get it, not a fan. Had an off putting taste that I can’t seem to describe but was always there.
This is the third time trying it because I was hoping my taste buds were off but still a no go for me. A permanent mixer from now on and I will not buy again.
This is amazing and lives up every bit to the hype.  It’s a $30 bottle and every bit as good as some at three times that price.   This is my new go to.

Nose - peanuts, leather, caramel, orange, light rye spice, vanilla, allspice, mild cinnamon, strong ethanol burn. 

Taste - rye spice, cinnamon, peanuts, caramel, vanilla, black pepper, allspice, black tea, moderate ethanol burn (less than expected given the proof).

This was better than I anticipated. I found it pleasantly complex and a great value for the price.
great bottle for the price. think its great to have around and will be keeping this stocked as a nice offering for guest. has nice complex flavors and a great proof.
Love this bourbon for the price. I taste a lot of chocolate in this one!
I guess I was hoping to be blown away or find an overlooked gem. It's decent but I was left wanting a bit more complexity. Prefer the knob creek 120 to this
Rye gives an ass kicking, cotton candy more than the candy corn from the expert notes, cinnamon spice, oaken vanilla, fruit and floral notes.
It should be called BFB “Big Fu%#ing Bourbon. Big flavor, high proof, $30 bucks! What else could you ask for.

Drinks a bit hot but stands up well in a cocktail. A little nutty and flows with a woody taste. It’s good, but first impression is that I would reach for this on its own very often. But in a cocktail is great
Definitely a sippable bourbon for the $30 price tag. Spicy to finish, smooth/rich on the tongue

So I was cooked earlier and I've discovered any smoke can really ruin a bourbon nose so I'm going off my last pour for nosing. It's caramel, nutty, sweet...more sweet than your knob creeks or bookers.

Taste - thankfully no issue on flavor for me here. It's nutty, bready, caramel, slight red fruits. Mouth feel is rich enough but not the super oily. 

So it's nice sipping whisky. I don't get any off flavor profile elements and that's really impressive with this being a 30 dollar higher proof offering. 

Heck 2.0 for me, a very high score but I can't find anything off here. I also don't really get anything special. It's a very basic sweet beam product but clean and refined in a way.
Ok I admit I am under the influence but i like this. Nose, first taste and finish are well above average. Sweet and fruit are enjoyable
Not bad, not great. Solid for the price. Pretty heavy oak flavors from what I remember? Not at all smooth, but a good pour.
Smooth with a little bit of spice to finish off, would make for a great pairing with a sweeter pipe tobacco or cigar!
Peanut funk and ethanol on the nose. Vanilla and toffee on the palate. Long finish. Better than average basic bourbon.

Nice mouthfeel before a delayed burn afterward. Heat lingers as well. I can’t distinguish many flavors in this one, but each sip seems to be its own experience. 
After trying this more, the rating went up. One of my new favorites!

The nose is a huge fiery burn of gasoline and rubbing alcohol. Singes those nose hairs. It's called 114 for a reason. Straight up, all other aromas fade to the background, although some corn and a little potpourri comes out. If you pour a drop of water in there, the burn only slightly subsides, but the spices emerge. 

The first taste is just a burn, pure and simple. As it mellows, cinnamon and dusty brown sugar come out. It's a good combo of sweet and spicy. There are autumnal spices like nutmeg, and cinnamon powder. If you add a droplet, some tobacco, leather and vanilla bust out. 

The finish is hot, as expected; the burn stays on the lips. Dry Cinnamon powder, nutmeg, dried leaves. Mellows off into a toffee and cut tobacco. This is a deceptively complex whiskey that rewards you for spending time with it.
Pretty smooth and flavorful for a $30 bottle. Loving the high abv. Nutty and buttery. Lots of thick body

Aroma- Vanilla, Honey and Booze / Taste - Vanilla and Char to the forefront. Citrus fades / finish- spice and vanilla

Great viscosity and "mouthfeel"

I've had this at bars and liked it a lot, but never purchased a bottle until recently. I'm clueless as to why since this is arguably the best value bourbon on the market.

My prior experience has been with rocks glasses only, and as a result the nose is much more interesting in a Glencairn. I smell some brown sugar, citrus peel, and cinnamon/nutmeg spice, not sure if it's more rye or oak age influence. What I did not get in a rocks glass is the dominant tea note. This is unlike most bourbons I've had (most similar to Four Roses Small Batch Select). I would equate this to a medium oxidized tea, something like oolong. Think of a dark green tea or light black tea if you haven't had oolong. It is unlike other high rye bourbons and barely legal ryes I've had recently.

I get more ethanol and spice on the tongue, which is expected at 114 proof. The spice lingers, medium to long finish that ends tannic. Overall it is an incredibly tasty and smooth bourbon for the price and proof. When you think about what's available for around $30, there are few options out there that comparable. When I finish this I'm buying another because it's going to be a staple on my shelf for cocktails and neat pours.
Sweet caramel, oak, hot (not spicy) well rounded
Drank Old Grand-dad with my old granddads. Nothing better.
Nice spice with a smooth butterscotch and vanilla taste.

Neat.  Neck pour.  Nuttiness and ethanol hit me first on the nose.  Some vanilla and mint.  Decent amount of cherry, I love finding cherry.  Baking spices.  Cinnamon.

Taste is a good translation of the nose.  Nice, creamy mouth feel.  Vanilla sweetness hits first, transitions to the cinnamon, cherry and leaves you with the nuttiness.

I would put this blind against Bakers.  I think it would hold its own.  There is a bit of ethanol that may hold it back from competing with Bakers and that makes sense too.  That is probably why it is where it is in price in the vertical.  A very very solid $30 bottle.
Let this one breathe a bit. Tastes much better after it opens up
Tart, oily. Smoky. A very different bourbon taste. Good, nearly great, not amazing. Beautiful color.
Excellent for the price point, warm and smooth
Hard to believe the ABV. Not as complex as the Rittenhouse.
Kind of a jack of all trades bourbon. Great for a cocktail, but still good neat or even on the rocks. High enough proof to make the feelings go away.
Spicy, leathery. Long and strong finish. This is the undercard of bourbons

Helluva kick. Definitely lives up to the name. Classic bourbon taste(spicy, cinnamon, vanilla, fruit) 

This reminds me a lot of Evan Williams Bottle In Bond. If they made that bottle cask strength, this would be it. This should be on your bucket list.
Spicy, but in a good way! The proof doesn't require water/ice to tone it down! Excellent pour for price point!
I feel like this tastes like what a non bourbon drinker thinks bourbon tastes like. Bold and spicy. Tobacco and leather. Like an old lazy-boy in a cigar bar. Very classic flavors.

Easy nose with hints of leather, spice. Nice full mouthfeel with some heat upfront on the palate. Finishes with a lot of spice, oak, and a bit of citrus. Not a very complex bourbon to me - originall picked up a lot of oak but it’s calmed since bottles been open. Liked it better with some water to bring down heat.
Love this one smells so good but lots of heat ! Great flavor for the price !
